Award.AwardTitle: Baltimore Ecosystem Study Phase III: Adaptive Processes in the Baltimore Socio-Ecological System from the Sanitary to the Sustainable City
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Baltimore Ecosystem Study (BES) was initiated as an LTER project in 1997, designed to understand the controls and interactions of urban ecosystem structure and function. This project will continue that long-term line of research and will expand it to address 3 fundamental issues: 1) The spatial and temporal relationships of socio-economic, ecological, and physical features of an urban area; 2) The fluxes of energy, matter, capital, and population in an urban area, and the development and relationships of these over time; and, 3) The ways in which people develop an understanding of the metropolis and use such understanding to reduce air and water pollution. The research integrates ecological, hydrologic, and social perspectives and research techniques to understand the human ecosystem and provide knowledge of relevance and utility for management of urban ecosystems and their neighboring environments.

This project contributes to understanding of the structure, function, and dynamics of a metropolitan area, and includes development of techniques for better understanding socio-ecological and urban ecosystems in general. It assembles and integrates valuable long-term data sets from paleoecological, historical, and contemporary time-frames. The project has broad societal value through its contributions to improved management of urban ecosystems and its focus on techniques for reducing environmental pollution and degradation. Its broader values also include extensive research-based training, educational program development, and public outreach programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Baltimore Ecosystem Study (BES), Long-Term Ecological Research project began in 1998 with the premise that familiar ecological ideas could be applied to understand the ecologically neglected topic of urban areas. That is, the Intellectual Merit of BES rests in the idea that urban areas were a legitimate topic for basic ecological research. BES used concepts of the ecosystem, the watershed, and patch dynamics. The ecosystem concept unites biological organisms with physical environments and can include people and constructed environments. The watershed is a powerful idea that uses the fact that the flow of water integrates biological, physical, and social processes. Patch dynamics assumes that spatial patterns and their effects on interactions are important to ecosystem function and change over time.

These major ideas are still fundamental to BES because they capture key things about how urban ecosystems function. The basic ecological questions address 1) how ecosystems are integrated, how urban ecosystems manage to hold onto limiting materials based on the internal relationships between sources and sinks of nutrients, contaminants, and organisms; 2) how ecosystem patterns at coarse and fine scales interact; and 3) feedbacks between pattern and process of biological, physical, social, and constructed ecosystem components. In addition, BES III focused on the transition from the sanitary city of the 19th and mid 20th centuries, to the emerging sustainable city of the 21st century. Intellectual Merit emerges from the new understanding of this unprecedented transition and Broader Impacts emerge from sharing these insights with those who guide this transition.

Answering the three fundamental questions of BES III have yielded important findings that have refined the big ideas of urban ecology. These include the findings that urban structures are hybrids of social-biophysical processes; the discovery of unexpected sinks and sources in the flow of materials and contaminants in urban systems; the interaction of regional versus local control of diversity of species and biological traits; the control of diversity by human management; the unexpected fragmentation emerging from regulations intended to reduce the environmental impact of subdivision, and the inadequacy of existing economic models in a shrinking neighborhoods that lack effective property markets.

Integration across the disciplines in urban ecology has resulted from sampling biological, physical, and social data in the same sites that reflect contrasting neighborhoods. The project also used quantitative models of watershed behavior, and data on the impact of rare social and biophysical events. Emphasis on co-production of joint ecological and social processes rather than coupling of separate human and natural subsystems is an advance that can reshape future long-term research on any human dominated system.

Specific contributions of BES III include these:

1. New Models of Urban Land Cover. The project has developed a new land cover system, which recognizes greater diversity than standard urban land use/land cover classifications.

2. The study of spatial patchiness has become more functionally oriented. The project has developed concepts that treat the origin and change of spatial patchiness as co-produced by biophysical and social processes through time.

3. The flow and quality of stream water, including limiting and polluting nutrients, sediment, and pharmaceutical and personal care products respond to climate extremes, disturbances, land cover changes, and human decisions about where to locate. New contaminants alter the metabolism of aquatic organisms, and hence modify stream ecosystem functions. Antibiotic contamination in streams may increase antibiotic resistance in stream bacteria, threatening human health.   

High nitrogen retention in Baltimore watersheds has revealed unexpected nitrogen sinks in lawns. Combining social survey and environmental chemistry showed that although fertilizer is a significant input in suburban watersheds, only ~50% of lawns are fertilized. Retention of this added nitrogen is high.

4. BES has contributed to the insight that urban biodiversity is often quite rich and contains important native elements. The contribution of urban biological diversity to material fluxes, particularly of nitrogen and carbon, occur in unexpected habitats.

5. Social survey indicated that variations in tree canopy cover across neighborhoods are positively associated with the desirability, environmental satisfaction, quality of life, and social cohesion experienced by residents. In an underserved urban watershed, green land management interventions were associated with increased neighborhood satisfaction, and increased outdoor recreation relative to the region.

6. An industry standard ecohydrological model has been revised to accommodate within-city green infrastructure, which is an advance beyond its early application in suburban watersheds. This achievement extends the broad utility of these models.

In short, BES helped establish modern American urban ecology as a science, but its Intellectual Merit continues as the project has evolved via new data, new concepts, and applications to the sustainable city transition. The evolution of BES in Phase III have helped guide the continued growth and integration of the broader science of urban ecology worldwide. BES III concepts and data have had Broader Impacts through urban policy, management, and design.
